item.title: Vector Bases and Coordinate Vectors
item.description: Building upon the concepts of vector spaces, linear combinations, span, and linear independence, we now delve into one of the most useful concepts in linear algebra: the vector basis ...

item.title: Linear Combinations
item.description: The vector axioms define the properties of scalar multiplication and vector addition, but often weâ€™ll seek to make use of both operations at once. This leads us to the more general concept of a linear combination.

item.title: Linear Independence
item.description: A linearly independent set A\equiv\{\vec{u}_1,\cdots,\vec{u}_n\} has the property that no element in A is a linear combination of any other elements (or lies within the span of ...

item.title: What is a Vector?
item.description: The most concise answer is that a vector \vec {u} is an element of a vector space \textbf{V}. In order for a set \textbf{V} to constitute a vector space, we require the existence of two operations on elements of \textbf{V} known as vector addition and scalar multiplication.
